mads.note: Brill's New Pauly: "Dionysius, Bishop of Rome (22 July AD 259/260 - 26 December 267/8). Probably from Greece, D. becomes bishop of Rome after the seat had been vacant for a long time. He reorganizes the community, which had been weakened by the Valerian persecution, on the basis of a presbyteral constitution. Following the request by Libyan presbyters, D. holds a synod, which condemned Sabellianism and a tritheistically influenced theory of the trinity as it was supported by bishop D. [52] of Alexandria. The reply from the Alexandrian D. gave rise to the ‘argument between the two Dionysii’. D., who was buried in the papal crypt of the Calixtus catacombs, is one of the most important Roman bishops of the 3rd cent...." Rist, Josef (Würzburg). “Dionysius”, in: Brill’s New Pauly, Antiquity volumes edited by: Hubert Cancik and , Helmuth Schneider. Consulted online on 28 October 2016
